item.title: Japanese English Loanword Nuances
item.description:

Various types of lingerie and bras and underwear and swimsuits and tights

リーズナブル
グッドボタン
ピンセット
ヤング
ダビング
ノーカン
ノーコン
ゲット
アフターサービス
オーブントースター
ガードマン
カンニング
ガソリンスタンド
ゴールデンタイム
サービスエリア
サイドブレーキ
ジェンダーレス
シャープペンシル
シャーペン
ブラック
ショートスリーパー
タッチパネル
ダンプカー
ドアミラー
トランプ
ビーチサンダル
ポテト
ナンバープレート
CAキャビンアテンダント
チャームポイント
レンジ
There are times where English speakers will use it in that way (like it does come from AN English meaning), and they'd probably understand if you said it, but it would sound really weird, also I'm too used to カタカナ英語 so I forget if these are understandable to people not exposed to Japan or not

スマート - "smartLY DRESSED" (あってる？?)
ファイト - "fight FOR IT"
タレント - can only really be use in the context of signing someone - for example "I have 3 talents signed to my label" "I own all the talent in LA" "I need new talents" (maybe? Or am I used to Japanese idols?)
アイドル - young people now use the word in the Asian way but older people would only use it in the possessive "my idol" or "I want to be an (someone's) idol"
ドラマチック - meaning is different when applied to people
ミス
ワンチャン - should be "a chance" in most situations
フラグ - most english speakers probably wouldn't understand at first, but if explained it doesn't really sound like incorrect or weird English (red flag is similar enough, although is less about foreshadowing future actions and more about revealing true nature)


"Japanese food"
Udon
Miso
Sake
Hibachi
Natto
Ramen, sushi, teriyaki, etc
Wasabi (most people know it's Japanese)
Nori
"Japanese things"
Katana
Kimono
Origami
Kaiju
Ninja
Samurai
Kamikaze
Kabuki
Koi
Sumo
Bonsai (most people know it's Japanese, otherwise "asian")
Haiku
Tanooki (a lot of people prob know bc of mario)
Shogun
Shinto
Geisha
Pokémon
Sensei
-san
arigato
Godzilla
Seppuku (not as well known )
"weeb things" (most people know it but it's less widely understood)
Anime
Manga
Weeb/meme slang
Otaku
Senpai/kouhai
Hentai
Ahegao
Bukkake
(Sussy) Baka
Keikaku (means plan)
-chan
Ahoge
"Asian things" (but some people might know they're Japanese)
Aikido
Dojo
Judo
Jujutsu (jiu jitsu)
Kendo
Karate
Soy (kinda)
Zen
Fugu
Mochi
Konnichiwa
"foreign words" (some people might know they're Japanese)
Tsunami
Shamisen
Typhoon (kinda but not really)
Shiitake
Umami
Sayonara
Karaoke
Ginkgo
Kanban
Banzai
The fact that it's Japanese is fun trivia
Tofu (apparently older people who were there when it was imported know it as an asian item)
Sudoku (maybe people don't know it's Japanese)
Kudzu
Shiba Inu
These are English words obviously
Futon
Emoji
Cosplay
Honcho
Rickshaw
Tycoon
Kancho
Karate, san, and bonsai are known to be Japanese by those who grew up when Karate kid came out
MANY gamer-nerd types know a ton of what you'd learn from casually watching subbed anime, and additionally a bit more about food such as mochi
Origami and haiku are taught in elementary school (and I think are taught to be Japanese)
Sumo, ninja, and samurai and VERY common in pop culture and are 100% known to be Japanese
Umami is taught in school but is not mentioned to be foreign or even japanese at all
Rickshaws I think have an association with Japan but the word looks distinctly american
Kamikaze is known by kids who have been taught about world war 2 and is often joked about
"sayonara sucker" and "head honcho" are said often in popular culture and by kids but don't have a Japanese or even asian association
Konnichiwa is a generic asian greeting
Tsunami and typhoon are just "the words for tidal waves and hurricanes in asia"
arigato is I think commonly known to be Japanese for thank you
Koi is very Japanese, but also associated with Zen which is not Japanese, if anything Chinese
Shogun and Shinto are taught in high school history classes
